sen.j: 土佐日記（とさにっき）は、紀貫之が土佐の国から京都まで帰京する最中に起きた出来事や思いなどを書いた日記。
sen.e: In The Tosa Diary, KI no Tsurayuki wrote about his thoughts and the events that happened on his journey from Tosa Province to Kyoto.
In "The Tosa Diary," KI no Tsurayuki wrote about his thoughts and the events that occurred on his journey from Tosa Province to Kyoto.
In "The Tosa Diary," KI no Tsurayuki wrote about his thoughts and the events that occurred on his journey from Tosa Province to Kyoto.

sen.j: 原本は土左日記（とさのにき）とあったとみられる。
sen.e: The original manuscript seems to have been called Tosa no Niki.
The original manuscript seems to have been called "Tosa no Niki."
The original manuscript seems to have been called "Tosa no Niki."

sen.j: 成立は935年（承平 (日本)5年）頃と言われる。
sen.e: It is said to have been completed around 935.
It is said to have been completed around 935.
It is said to have been completed around 935.

sen.j: 930年（延長 (元号)8年）から934年（承平4年）土佐国の国司だった貫之が、任期を終えて土佐から京へ戻るまでの55日間の紀行を、女の作者を装って平仮名で綴った。
sen.e: Tsurayuki, who had been Kokushi of Tosa Province from 930 to 934, wrote about his 55-day journey from Tosa to Kyoto after he served out his term, pretending to be a female writer and using Hiragana.

Tsurayuki, who had been the kokushi of Tosa Province from 930 to 934, wrote about his 55-day journey from Tosa to Kyoto after he had served out his term, pretending to be a female writer and using Hiragana.

Tsurayuki, who had been the kokushi of Tosa Province from 930 to 934, wrote about his 55-day journey from Tosa to Kyoto after he had served out his term, pretending to be a female writer and using Hiragana.

sen.j: この時代男性の日記は漢文で書くのが当たり前であり、そのため、紀貫之に従った女性と言う設定で書かれた。
sen.e: In this time it was common for men to write a diary in Chinese characters, and that is why he wrote it pretending to be a woman who served him.
In this time it was common for men to write a diary in Chinese characters, and that is why he wrote it pretending to be a woman who served him.
In this time it was common for men to write a diary in Chinese characters, and that is why he wrote it pretending to be a woman who served him.

sen.j: 57首の和歌も含まれている。
sen.e: It includes 57 waka poems, too.
It includes 57 waka poems, too.
It includes 57 waka poems, too.

sen.j: 執筆の内容はさまざまであるが、中心には土佐国で亡くなった愛娘を思う心情である。
sen.e: The contents of writing are diverse, but he focused on writing especially his love for his daughter who passed away in Tosa Province.
The contents of the writing are diverse, but he gave particular emphasis to his love for his daughter, who passed away in Tosa Province.
The contents of the writing are diverse, but he gave particular emphasis to his love for his daughter, who passed away in Tosa Province.

sen.j: この悲嘆を距離を置いて描く為に、男性の自身や従者でなく、仕える女房という体裁をとったとも考えられている。
sen.e: It is also considered that in order to write his lament objectively, he didn't write it from the male point of view such as Tsurayuki himself or his servant, but from a court lady's view.
It is also considered that in order to write his lament objectively, he didn't write it from the male point of view such as Tsurayuki himself or his servant, but from a court lady's view.
It is also considered that in order to write his lament objectively, he didn't write it from the male point of view such as Tsurayuki himself or his servant, but from a court lady's view.

sen.j: 日本文学史上、おそらく初めての『日記文学』であったが、現代の日記というより紀行に近い要素ももっていた。
sen.e: In the history of Japanese literature, it was probably the first "diary literature," but it was approximate to a travelogue rather than the present diary.
In the history of Japanese literature it was probably the first "diary literature," but it was approximate to a travelogue rather than the present diary.
In the history of Japanese literature it was probably the first "diary literature," but it was approximate to a travelogue rather than the present diary.

sen.j: その後の平仮名による表現、特に女流文学の発達に大きな影響を与えている。
sen.e: It exerted a great influence on the later writing in Hiragana and the development of the literature by women.
It had a great influence on the later writing in Hiragana and the development of women's literature.
It had a great influence on the later writing in Hiragana and the development of women's literature.

sen.j: 『蜻蛉日記』、『和泉式部日記』、『紫式部日記』、『更級日記』などの作品にも影響を及ぼした可能性は高い。
sen.e: There is a strong possibility that it had great influences on "Kagero Diary (The Gossamer Years)," "Izumi Shikibu Diary," "Murasaki Shikibu Diary," "Sarashina Nikki (Diary)," etc.
There is a strong possibility that it had great influences on "Kagero Diary (The Gossamer Years)," "Izumi Shikibu Diary," "Murasaki Shikibu Diary," "Sarashina Nikki (Diary)," etc.
There is a strong possibility that it had great influences on "Kagero Diary (The Gossamer Years)," "Izumi Shikibu Diary," "Murasaki Shikibu Diary," "Sarashina Nikki (Diary)," etc.

sen.j: 貫之自筆本は現存しないが、15世紀末までは蓮華王院の宝蔵に蔵されており、その間に藤原定家（1235年）・藤原為家（1236年）・松本宗綱（1490年）・三条西実隆（1492年）らにより書写された以下の4系統が知られる。
sen.e: Manuscript written in Tsurayuki's own handwriting has not survived, but it had been preserved in the treasure house in the Rengeoin until the end of 15th century, and the following 4 lines of manuscript, copied by FUJIWARA no Sadaie (1235), FUJIWARA no Tameie (1236), Munetsuna MATSUMOTO (1490), and Sanetaka SANJONISHI (1492), are well known.
sen.cmt: 写本の訳語はmanuscriptで統一しました。http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=蓮華王院&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=22860519580100http://spysee.jp/藤原定家http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=藤原為家&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=18720316093100http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=三条西実隆&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=08846907592400「松本宗綱」の読み方不明。
sen.e: The manuscript in Tsurayuki's own handwriting has not survived, but it had been preserved in the treasure house in the Rengeoin until the end of the fifteenth century, and the following four lines of manuscript, copied by FUJIWARA no Sadaie (1235), FUJIWARA no Tameie (1236), Munetsuna MATSUMOTO (1490) and Sanetaka SANJONISHI (1492), are well known.

The manuscript in Tsurayuki's own handwriting has not survived, but it had been preserved in the treasure house in the Rengeoin until the end of the fifteenth century, and the following four lines of manuscript, copied by FUJIWARA no Sadaie (1235), FUJIWARA no Tameie (1236), Munetsuna MATSUMOTO (1490) and Sanetaka SANJONISHI (1492), are well known.

sen.j: わけても定家本は巻末の2面を臨摸しており、原本が失われた今となっては貫之の文字遣いを知ることの出来る極めて貴重な存在となっている。
sen.e: Above all, Teikabon includes 2-page writing following the model at the end of the book, and it came to be very important in order to know Tsurayuki's diction today, when the original has been lost.
Above all, Teikabon includes two-page writing (following the model) at the end of the book, and it came to be very important in order to know Tsurayuki's diction today, since the original is lost.
Above all, Teikabon includes two-page writing (following the model) at the end of the book, and it came to be very important in order to know Tsurayuki's diction today, since the original is lost.

sen.j: ちなみに、臨摸した部分以外については、定家は原本の仮名遣によらず自ら考案した定家仮名遣に従って書き直しているが、子の為家の書写本は臨摸まではしていないものの、原本の仮名遣通りに書写しているため、本全体としては為家書写本が最善本という評価を与えられている。
sen.e: By the way, Sadaie rewrote the whole manuscript except the part which he followed the model, depending on not the original use of Kana but on the Teika Kanazukai (the distinction of using Kana in the same pronunciation), which he invented, while his son Tameie didn't write following the model but copied the manuscript in the same way of using Kana as the original, therefore the copy written by Tameie is considered to be the best version of the book as a whole.

Incidentally, Sadaie rewrote the entire manuscript except for the part in which he followed the model, depending not on the original use of Kana but on the Teika Kanazukai (the distinction of using Kana in the same pronunciation), which he invented, while his son Tameie didn't write by following the model but copied the manuscript in the same way of using Kana as the original; thus the copy written by Tameie is considered to be the best version of the book as a whole.

Incidentally, Sadaie rewrote the entire manuscript except for the part in which he followed the model, depending not on the original use of Kana but on the Teika Kanazukai (the distinction of using Kana in the same pronunciation), which he invented, while his son Tameie didn't write by following the model but copied the manuscript in the same way of using Kana as the original; thus the copy written by Tameie is considered to be the best version of the book as a whole.

sen.j: 池田亀鑑は諸本の研究の上、120種以上に及ぶ写本群から自筆本再構のために証本を選んだ。
sen.e: Kikan IKEDA chose the Shohon (premised book) among more than 120 versions of manuscript to reconstruct the original book after studying them.
Kikan IKEDA chose the Shohon (premised book) among more than 120 versions of the manuscript in order to reconstruct the original work.
Kikan IKEDA chose the Shohon (premised book) among more than 120 versions of the manuscript in order to reconstruct the original work.

sen.j: 元和 (日本)・寛永のころになって註釈的研究が盛んになり、岸本由豆流が諸抄論においてあげた『土佐日記聞書』などは、その最初のものである。
sen.e: Around the 17th century, when the study of commentary became popular, "Oral records of The Tosa Diary" was written by Yuzuru KISHIMOTO in the various Shoron, and became the first example.
sen.cmt: 「元和」年号（1615.7.13～1624.2.30）「寛永」年号（1624.2.30～1644.12.16）元和・寛永はまとめて「around the 17th century」としました。http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=岸本由豆流&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=05026404194000http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/
sen.e: Around the seventeenth century, when the study of commentary became popular, "Oral Records of the Tosa Diary" was written by Yuzuru KISHIMOTO in the various shoron, becoming the first example.
Around the seventeenth century, when the study of commentary became popular, "Oral Records of the Tosa Diary" was written by Yuzuru KISHIMOTO in the various shoron, becoming the first example.

sen.j: 加藤盤斎の『土佐日記見聞抄』は年代がなく成立年は不明であるが、万治4（1661年）年の跋がある人見卜幽の『土佐日記附注』、北村季吟の『土佐日記抄』などと同時期のものであるらしい。
sen.e: "The Tosa Diary's Experiences Abstract" written by Bansai KATO doesn't have the year of creation in the book, but it seems to have be written around the same time when "The Tosa Diary with Note" by Bokuyu HITOMI, which has the postscript dated 1661, and "The Tosa Diary's Abstract" by Kigin KITAMURA were completed.

"The Tosa Diary's Experiences Abstract," written by Bansai KATO, doesn't have the year of creation in the book, but it seems to have been written around the same time that "The Tosa Diary with Note" by Bokuyu HITOMI, which has a postscript dated 1661, and "The Tosa Diary's Abstract" (by Kigin KITAMURA) were completed.

"The Tosa Diary's Experiences Abstract," written by Bansai KATO, doesn't have the year of creation in the book, but it seems to have been written around the same time that "The Tosa Diary with Note" by Bokuyu HITOMI, which has a postscript dated 1661, and "The Tosa Diary's Abstract" (by Kigin KITAMURA) were completed.

sen.j: 本居宣長は『土佐日記抄』には『土佐日記附注』の影響が見られるとするが、岸本由豆流は、両書で引用している古典籍の相違が説明できないと指摘している。
sen.e: Norinaga MOTOORI said there seemed to be an influence of "The Tosa Diary with Note" on "The Tosa Diary's Abstract," but Yuzuru KISHIMOTO pointed out that it was impossible to explain the differences between the venerable classics quoted in both books.
sen.cmt: 「古典籍」の訳語は、Kenkyusha Online Dictionary 追加語彙（和英）による。
sen.e: Norinaga MOTOORI said there seemed to be an influence of "The Tosa Diary with Note" on "The Tosa Diary's Abstract," but Yuzuru KISHIMOTO pointed out that it was impossible to explain the differences between the venerable classics quoted in both books.

Norinaga MOTOORI said there seemed to be an influence of "The Tosa Diary with Note" on "The Tosa Diary's Abstract," but Yuzuru KISHIMOTO pointed out that it was impossible to explain the differences between the venerable classics quoted in both books.

sen.j: 寛永4年5月に刊行された『土佐日記首書』は、ほとんど『土佐日記抄』のままである。
sen.e: "The Tosa Diary with comments" made in May, 1627 was almost the same as "The Tosa Diary with Note."
"The Tosa Diary with Comments," made in May 1627, was nearly the same as "The Tosa Diary with Notes."
"The Tosa Diary with Comments," made in May 1627, was nearly the same as "The Tosa Diary with Notes."

sen.j: 加藤宇万伎は、契沖と賀茂真淵との説を併記した『土佐日記註』を書いた。
sen.e: Umaki KATO wrote "The Tosa Diary's Interpretation," in which the both views of Keichu and KAMO no Mabuchi were included.
Umaki KATO wrote "The Tosa Diary's Interpretation," in which the views of both Keichu and KAMO no Mabuchi were included.
Umaki KATO wrote "The Tosa Diary's Interpretation," in which the views of both Keichu and KAMO no Mabuchi were included.

sen.j: また上田秋成は、真淵の説に自らの説を添えたものを刊行している。
sen.e: Also, Akinari UEDA added his own view to the Mabuchi's theory and published the book.
Also, Akinari UEDA added his own view to the Mabuchi's theory and published the book.
Also, Akinari UEDA added his own view to the Mabuchi's theory and published the book.

sen.j: さらに真淵の説は、楫取魚彦によって、別に書き記され、『土佐日記打聞』や『土佐日記聞書』となった。
sen.e: Besides, Mabuchi's theory was rewritten by Nahiko KATORI, and was brought out as "The Tosa Diary's Overhearing" and "The Tosa Diary Verbatim Record."
sen.cmt: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=楫取魚彦&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=04206503455000『土佐日記聞書』の定訳不明
sen.e: Moreover, Mabuchi's theory was rewritten by Nahiko KATORI and brought out as "The Tosa Diary Overheard" and "The Tosa Diary Verbatim Record."
Moreover, Mabuchi's theory was rewritten by Nahiko KATORI and brought out as "The Tosa Diary Overheard" and "The Tosa Diary Verbatim Record."

sen.j: 『土佐日記註』と『土佐日記打聞』とで説の相違があるのを、岸本は、「魚彦がしるせるは県居翁の早くの説、宇万伎がしるせるは、後の説なるべし」としている。
sen.e: KISHIMOTO explained the differences between "The Tosa Diary's Interpretation" and "The Tosa Diary's Overhearing," saying that 'What Nahiko wrote is the earlier theory of Agatai no Okina, and what Umaki wrote is the later one.'

KISHIMOTO explained the differences between "The Tosa Diary's Interpretation" and "The Tosa Diary Overheard," saying that 'What Nahiko wrote is the earlier theory of Agatai no Okina, and what Umaki wrote is the later one.'

KISHIMOTO explained the differences between "The Tosa Diary's Interpretation" and "The Tosa Diary Overheard," saying that 'What Nahiko wrote is the earlier theory of Agatai no Okina, and what Umaki wrote is the later one.'

sen.j: 岸本由豆流は、のち、『土佐日記考証』（文化 (元号)12（1815年）年ごろか）をあらわし、諸抄を取捨選択、綿密な考証をこころみ、富士谷御杖は『土佐日記灯』をあらわして一大研究をうちたてた。
sen.e: Yuzuru KISHIMOTO published "A Study of The Tosa Diary" later (around 1818), picking and choosing some abstracts and checking them very closely, while Mitsue FUJITANI wrote her major work of "The Tosa Diary's Study."

Yuzuru KISHIMOTO later published "A Study of the Tosa Diary" (around 1818), picking and choosing some abstracts and checking them very closely, while Mitsue FUJITANI wrote her major work, "The Tosa Diary's Study."

Yuzuru KISHIMOTO later published "A Study of the Tosa Diary" (around 1815), picking and choosing some abstracts and checking them very closely, while Mitsue FUJITANI wrote her major work, "Study of the Tosa Diary."

sen.j: 香川景樹も『土佐日記創見』（文政6（1823年）年）を著し、綿密な考証をなしている。
sen.e: Kageki KAGAWA also wrote "The Tosa Diary's New Remarks" (in 1823), ascertaining historical evidence in detail.
Kageki KAGAWA also wrote "The Tosa Diary's New Remarks" (in 1823), ascertaining historical evidence in detail.
Kageki KAGAWA also wrote "The Tosa Diary's New Remarks" (in 1823), ascertaining historical evidence in detail.

sen.j: この3著は研究史上重要なものである。
sen.e: These 3 books are important in the history of the study.
These three books are important in the history of the study.
These three books are important in the history of the study.

sen.j: これらの研究は本文批評や諸本研究上高い成かをもたらしただけでなく、文体、動機などにまで論を推し進めている。
sen.e: These study are not only brilliant achievements in the textual criticism and a study of the versions of the book, but they took a closer look at the issue of style and motive.
These studies are not only brilliant achievements in textual criticism and as studies of the versions of the book, but they also take a closer look at the issue of style and motive.
These studies are not only brilliant achievements in textual criticism and as studies of the versions of the book, but they also take a closer look at the issue of style and motive.

sen.j: 明治にいたって前田家本や三条西家本が公開され、橘純一や山田孝雄などによって本文研究が進められた。
sen.e: In the Meiji era, Maedakebon and Sanjonishikebon were revealed, and textual criticism was conducted by Junichi TACHIBANA and Yoshio YAMADA etc.
In the Meiji period Maedakebon and Sanjonishikebon were revealed, and textual criticism was conducted by Junichi TACHIBANA and Yoshio YAMADA, etc.
In the Meiji period Maedakebon and Sanjonishikebon were revealed, and textual criticism was conducted by Junichi TACHIBANA and Yoshio YAMADA, etc.

sen.j: わけても、原本を忠実に写したとされる青谿書屋本などをもとにして池田亀鑑がなした『古典の批判的処置に関する研究』（1941年）にいたってほとんど完成するに至った。
sen.e: Above all, Kikan IKEDA wrote "A Study on Critical Dealing with the Classics" concerning with Seikeishookubon, which is said to have been copied true to the original manuscript, and brought his study to near completion
sen.cmt: 『古典の批判的処置に関する研究』の定訳不明
sen.e: Above all, Kikan IKEDA wrote "A Study on Critical Dealing with the Classics" concerning himself with the Seikeishookubon, which is said to have been copied true to the original manuscript, and brought his study near to completion.

Above all, Kikan IKEDA wrote "A Study on Critical Dealing with the Classics" (1941), concerning himself with the Seikeishookubon, which is said to have been copied true to the original manuscript, and brought his study near to completion.
